awd_titl_txt: The construction and evaluation of trust in a cryptomarket
awd_abstract_narration:
The goals of this project are to identify the conditions that 1) allow illicit online drug markets to emerge and evolve, 2) enable drug dealers to distribute drugs to customers and 3) incentivize buyers to purchase illegal drugs on the market. In less than ten years, we have witnessed an unprecedented rise and spread of illegal online cryptomarkets, especially those that traffic in illegal drugs, on the "darknet" -- an encrypted region of the Internet only accessible via anonymous 'Tor' browsers. Unlike surface web markets, on the darknet sellers' and buyers' identities are protected through encryption software and the use of cryptocurrency. Such identity protection measures make the darknet particularly appealing to those engaging in illegal behaviors, including trafficking in illegal drugs. This project will advance knowledge in several key domains by integrating insights from criminal, economic, and sociological theories to understand the importance of trust for creating and maintaining social order on illegal drug markets on the darknet, including: a) revealing how trust is signaled, managed, and used by dealers and buyers engaging in illegal drug trade, b) determining whether and how the importance of different trust-signaling strategies enhance dealers' marketability or change over the career of a drug dealer or with buyer experience, c) evaluating the effect of attacks to dealers' reputations as trustworthy trade partners, as well as how dealers resolve such moments of conflict when their trustworthiness is questioned, and d) assessing whether and how trust can be leveraged to disrupt drug trade on the darknet and reduce illegal online drug trade. The current study will provide critical information that law enforcement can leverage when considering strategies that have potential to disrupt the illegal drug trade on the darknet. 

To address these goals, longitudinal network and text data will be collected from three popular drug cryptomarkets operating on the darknet covering the time periods of October 2014—January 2020. Each of these cryptomarkets include temporal information on all drug transactions occurring in the market and the network of ties between dealers and buyers engaging in trade as well as textual information from dealers’ landing page, reviewer comments, and discussion board posts. Data will be analyzed by combining qualitative discourse analysis, natural language processing, statistical methods for network analysis including ERGMs and relational events models, growth-curve trajectory models, and agent-based simulation models for assessing the consequences of market disruptions. By leveraging a variety of data available from these cryptomarkets, we can qualitatively identify the processes through which trust emerges, cooperation evolves, and conflicts are resolved, and then quantify these processes through computational text mining. The unprecedented level of detail available in the collected data provides a novel opportunity to monitor online drug market dynamics, as well as the opportunity to observe the real-time consequences of changes in drug policy, the impact of drug epidemics, the emergence of new psychotropic substances, the role of distributed trust for facilitating market activity, and the effectiveness of different law enforcement disruption strategies.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Social, Behavioral and Economic Sciences
org_div_long_name: Division of Social and Economic Sciences

por.por_cntn:
This project aimed to uncover and comprehend the factors leading to the emergence and growth of illegal online drug markets, how they facilitate drug distribution among dealers and buyers, and what drives buyers to engage in purchasing illegal substances on these platforms.

Our study provided the first comprehensive sociological understanding of online illegal drug markets. Our findings illustrate the expanding role of illicit online trade and its relevance for understanding broader exchange challenges encountered in all illegal trade settings. Examining the effects of online illegal trade on consumption and supply-side policing, our findings reveal both actor and network-based mechanisms that facilitate trust, encourage trade, and lead to increased prices, vendor loyalty, and poly-drug purchasing. Overall, our research emphasizes a network perspective's efficacy for understanding online illegal drug markets, emphasizing its relevance in assessing trade and discussion networks, technical innovation, and market evolution and vulnerabilities. Below, we describe more specific findings emerging from our project.

In studying the expansion and evolution of online illicit markets, economic sociology has traditionally focused on the influence of social networks on economic behavior. However, little research has explored how the structures of these networks impact pricing within the unregulated and risky realm of online criminal commerce. Unlike previous studies on online markets, we propose that the precarious nature of illegal trade intensifies the reliance of market participants on social connections that naturally arise from drug trading networks. By modeling an online illegal drug market as a network of drug transactions between sellers and buyers, we were able to assess whether these network structures influenced the growth patterns of the market and the volume of drug transactions between buyers and sellers. We examine how "overembeddedness," characterized by excessive interconnectedness among market participants, emerges from internal trade relations to affect prices in illegal online markets, ultimately impacting short-term revenue.

Through dynamic panel models, we discover that increases in closure and repeated exchanges drive up illegal drug prices until a saturation point is reached, after which prices and monthly revenue decline as networks become overly interconnected. These findings shed light on the network dynamics shaping prices and revenue in illegal online drug trade, highlighting how network structure influences pricing even in anonymous trading environments.

Further analysis unveils a well-organized trade network characterized by dense clusters and frequent recurring drug exchanges. Dynamic network models demonstrate that both embeddedness and closure in exchange structures also accelerate the rate of illegal drug trading occurring within the market, with effects comparable to those of buyers’ reputation based on reviews left by previous buyers. These network effects are most pronounced in the early stages of market development but diminish as the market matures. Drug sellers engaged in repeated exchange relationships and bicliques establish reputations more rapidly in the early stages of market development compared to non-embedded sellers. Additionally, buyers are more inclined to purchase a new type of drug when the transaction is part of an indirect network referral, where a friend-of-a-friend endorses the buyer. While histories of exchange increase overall drug purchasing frequency, they are linked to decreases in purchases of new drug types. These processes contribute either to an integrated market, where buyers acquire multiple drugs from various vendors (via referrals) or to a fragmented market characterized by recurrent trades from the same vendors for the same substances (through repeated trade). Overall, these findings highlight the significant, time-sensitive influence of transaction networks on illegal trade in online markets, illustrating how internal economic networks can facilitate risky exchanges under conditions of anonymity and illegality.

The secondary objective of this research was to use natural language processing and machine learning to understand the trust signals vendors use to attract buyers and to understand how vendors and buyers migrate across different dark web drug marketplaces. 

Vendors and buyers on darknet markets usually worry about leaving a digital trail and need a secure, highly anonymous environment to exchange information while safeguarding their online privacy. Our stylometry findings indicate that the risk of exposure within anonymous communities mostly comes from the diversity of information presented stylistically rather than the network connections between vendors, buyers, and items purchased. This aligns with contemporary research in the area.  A notable outcome of this research is how stylometry may be leveraged to not only understand trust signals in such networks but also to better understand how vendors and buyers migrate across different dark web drug marketplaces.

From a methods standpoint our findings suggest that coupling content with graph structure (forum access, posts) can help improve stylometry performance. We also observe distinctions in effectiveness of stylometry methods across clear web and dark web forum posts and note that pre-training on clear-web data can help improve stylometry analysis on the dark web.

Finally, the project has developed new efforts for parallel scraping and integrating data from multiple dark- and clear-net sources.

 


Last Modified: 05/29/2024
Modified by: Dana L Haynie
